statement.text: Mechanical thrombectomy using aspiration or rheolytic devices has emerged as a first-line endovascular treatment for acute mesenteric arterial occlusion, offering rapid revascularization with lower bleeding risk compared to catheter-directed thrombolysis, and increasingly replacing pharmacological lysis in contemporary practice.
statement.formal: Mechanical Thrombectomy: Aspiration (Indigo, Penumbra CAT) → Suction removes thrombus; Rheolytic (AngioJet) → Saline jet fragmentation + aspiration; Technical success: 80-95%; Advantages: Rapid, lower bleeding vs CDT; May combine with CDT or angioplasty/stenting

explanation.intuition: Time is bowel—every hour of ischemia increases the extent of irreversible necrosis. Traditional catheter-directed thrombolysis (CDT) could take 12-24+ hours, during which bowel injury continues. Mechanical thrombectomy can restore flow in minutes to hours, reducing the ischemic burden and potentially salvaging more bowel.
explanation.key_insight: The shift from thrombolysis to mechanical thrombectomy mirrors the evolution in stroke and pulmonary embolism treatment. Rapid clot removal is preferable to slow dissolution. Modern aspiration devices can effectively remove large thrombus volumes with minimal adjunctive lysis.
explanation.technical_details: Large-bore aspiration catheters (6-8 Fr) can directly engage and aspirate soft thrombus. Rheolytic devices create a Venturi effect to fragment and remove clot. Combination strategies (aspiration + local lysis + angioplasty) are common. Post-thrombectomy imaging assesses need for stenting of underlying lesion.

primary_indications.rationale: Fresh thrombus amenable to aspiration; distal to proximal branches
primary_indications.typical_approach: Aspiration first; CDT as adjunct if residual

primary_indications.rationale: May have underlying stenosis requiring angioplasty/stenting after clot removal
Thrombosed stenosis; clot removal + stenting of underlying lesion

relative_contraindications: Very chronic (organized) thrombus resistant to aspiration
Small vessel embolism inaccessible to catheters
Extensive necrosis already present (may still offer palliation)

aspiration_catheters.mechanism: Direct suction applied to thrombus face via large-bore catheter
technique_tips: Advance catheter to thrombus face under fluoroscopy
advantages: Can be combined with other techniques

examples.name: AngioJet
examples.mechanism: Saline jet creates Venturi effect; aspirates fragmented thrombus

rheolytic_devices.mechanism: High-velocity saline jets fragment thrombus while Venturi effect aspirates debris
cautions: Bradycardia risk (adenosine release—less of issue in mesenteric than coronary)

mechanical_fragmentation.use: Adjunctive; helps break up thrombus for aspiration

access.approach: Usually femoral; brachial alternative if antegrade approach needed
access.sheath_size: 7-8 Fr typically for large aspiration catheters

procedure_steps.purpose: Confirm occlusion, assess extent, identify embolic vs thrombotic

procedure_steps.caution: Avoid subintimal passage in native vessel

procedure_steps.action: Advance aspiration catheter to thrombus face

procedure_steps.purpose: Remove thrombus en bloc if possible
Evaluate flow restoration, residual thrombus, underlying stenosis
Confirm adequate flow; assess bowel blush

clinical_outcomes.bowel_salvage: Depends on time to reperfusion and extent of injury pre-procedure
clinical_outcomes.bowel_resection_rate: Still required in many (30-50%) even after successful revascularization

comparison_to_cdt.efficacy: Similar or superior when appropriate devices used
comparison_to_cdt.current_trend: Mechanical thrombectomy first-line; CDT as adjunct

pharmaco_mechanical.rationale: Address bulk thrombus mechanically, then low-dose lysis for residual
pharmaco_mechanical.dose: Lower lytic doses than standalone CDT (e.g., tPA 0.5-1 mg/hr)

thrombectomy_plus_stenting.approach: Remove thrombus, then stent underlying stenosis
thrombectomy_plus_stenting.rationale: Treat acute occlusion and prevent recurrence

procedure_related.management: Further aspiration, CDT, accept if minor branches

clinical_pearls.pearl: Aspiration thrombectomy has largely replaced standalone CDT for acute SMA occlusion—faster revascularization and lower bleeding risk
clinical_pearls.implication: Consider aspiration first-line when endovascular approach selected

clinical_pearls.pearl: Fresh thrombus (embolic, <7-14 days) is most amenable to aspiration; organized thrombus may require adjunctive measures
clinical_pearls.implication: Assess thrombus characteristics on initial angiography to plan approach

clinical_pearls.pearl: Mechanical thrombectomy can restore flow in minutes, but bowel viability still depends on pre-procedure ischemia time
clinical_pearls.implication: Speed of decision-making matters more than speed of the procedure

clinical_pearls.pearl: Even with successful revascularization, bowel resection is often still needed—have surgical backup and plan for second-look
clinical_pearls.implication: Endovascular success ≠ clinical success; assess bowel viability after reperfusion
